title: Airplane Delays
text:
1 Introduction
On average, flight delays cost the U.S. economy $285 million and $580 million per day (FAA). It also affects 236 million travellers, almost 1 in 4 passengers, each year (Airhelp). To understand where and why these delays occur, we will analyse the on-time statistics and delay causes of U.S. domestic flights from January to June 2025. Our analysis will answer two key questions: (1) Do U.S. airports fall into distinct operational delay profiles, and what drives the differences between those profiles? (2) Which delay causes the greatest cost across the system? By examining five delay categories across major airlines and airports, we can identify systemic patterns as well as airport-specific challenges that could guide future operational improvements.

title: 2  Data
text:
2.1 Description
This data comes from the United States Department of Transportation’s Bureau of Transportation Statistics and contains information on flight delays and cancellations for domestic flights in the first six months of 2025. In that time period, there were a total of 11,404 delayed operations by 21 airlines at 370 airports.
Each observation represents aggregated monthly statistics for a specific airport-airline combination (i.e. HOU-Southwest-January or IAD-Delta-May). There are 21 variables representing flight volumes, delay counts, delay durations, cancellations and diversions. A flight is considered delayed if it arrives more than 15 minutes after its scheduled time.
Key Delay Categories (each measured in both count and minutes):
It is important to note that the delay time and delay count metrics capture different aspects of performance; an airport could have many short delays (high count, low time) or a few very long delays (low count, high time), so both dimensions must be considered in the analysis. Additionally, because airports and airlines vary significantly in size, performance comparisons will need to be normalised by the total number of incoming flights to create meaningful per-flight delay rates.

title: 2  Data
text:
Carrier delays: airline-controlled issues (maintenance, crew, baggage) 
Weather delays: extreme weather conditions
NAS delays: National Airspace System issues (air traffic control, non-extreme weather, high volume) 
Security delays 
Late aircraft delays

title: 3  Results
text:
3.1 Q1. How do delay patterns vary across U.S. airports and states, and how are these patterns associated with geography, dominant delay types, and airport traffic volume?
Code
library(tidyverse)
library(GGally)
library(janitor)
library(statebins)
library(ggplot2)

df <- read_csv("Airline_Delay_Cause.csv")
df
